<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 194, 220, 209]]<|/det|>
# MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 216, 356, 233]]<|/det|>
Paper 3 Pure Mathematics 3 (P3)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 259, 460, 303]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Answer Booklet/Paper Graph Paper List of Formulae (MF9)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[760, 195, 907, 210]]<|/det|>
9709/31  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[784, 217, 907, 233]]<|/det|>
May/June 2011  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[760, 240, 907, 255]]<|/det|>
1 hour 45 minutes  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 320, 390, 338]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 351, 828, 367]]<|/det|>
If you have been given an Answer Booklet, follow the instructions on the front cover of the Booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 368, 722, 384]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 384, 325, 400]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 400, 497, 416]]<|/det|>
You may use a soft pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 416, 601, 433]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 447, 284, 463]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 463, 907, 495]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 494, 590, 510]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 510, 606, 526]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 540, 606, 556]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 556, 756, 572]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 572, 440, 588]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 75.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 588, 907, 620]]<|/det|>
Questions carrying smaller numbers of marks are printed earlier in the paper, and questions carrying larger numbers of marks later in the paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
Expand \(\sqrt[3]{(1 - 6x)}\) in ascending powers of \(x\) up to and including the term in \(x^{3}\), simplifying the coefficients. [4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 138, 97, 158]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 134, 435, 163]]<|/det|>
Find \(\frac{\mathrm{dy}}{\mathrm{dx}}\) in each of the following cases:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 170, 146, 188]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 170, 304, 188]]<|/det|>
\(y = \ln (1 + \sin 2x)\),

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 170, 920, 188]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 198, 143, 216]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 196, 240, 222]]<|/det|>
\(y = \frac{\tan x}{x}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 200, 920, 218]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 250, 96, 269]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 250, 920, 286]]<|/det|>
Points \(A\) and \(B\) have coordinates \((-1, 2, 5)\) and \((2, -2, 11)\) respectively. The plane \(p\) passes through \(B\) and is perpendicular to \(AB\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 297, 728, 317]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>Find an equation of \(p\), giving your answer in the form \(ax + by + cz = d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 298, 920, 316]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 327, 151, 346]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 327, 529, 346]]<|/det|>
Find the acute angle between \(p\) and the \(y\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 329, 920, 346]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 374, 97, 393]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 374, 393, 393]]<|/det|>
The polynomial \(\operatorname {f}(x)\) is defined by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[381, 400, 616, 420]]<|/det|>
\[\operatorname {f}(x) = 12x^{3} + 25x^{2} - 4x - 12.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 439, 154, 457]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 439, 561, 458]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\operatorname {f}(-2) = 0\) and factorise \(\operatorname {f}(x)\) completely.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 440, 920, 458]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 470, 148, 488]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 470, 245, 488]]<|/det|>
Given that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[354, 490, 645, 508]]<|/det|>
\[12\times 27^{\mathrm{y}} + 25\times 9^{\mathrm{y}} - 4\times 3^{\mathrm{y}} - 12 = 0,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 513, 700, 533]]<|/det|>
state the value of \(3^{\mathrm{y}}\) and hence find \(y\) correct to 3 significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 514, 920, 532]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 560, 96, 579]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 560, 316, 579]]<|/det|>
The curve with equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[418, 580, 579, 599]]<|/det|>
\[6\mathrm{e}^{2x} + k\mathrm{e}^{y} + \mathrm{e}^{2y} = c,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 604, 792, 624]]<|/det|>
where \(k\) and \(c\) are constants, passes through the point \(P\) with coordinates \((\ln 3, \ln 2)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 636, 153, 655]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 636, 341, 655]]<|/det|>
Show that \(58 + 2k = c\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 636, 920, 655]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 666, 153, 685]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 666, 774, 685]]<|/det|>
Given also that the gradient of the curve at \(P\) is \(-6\), find the values of \(k\) and \(c\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 666, 920, 685]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[391, 81, 640, 243]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 260, 920, 312]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a circle with centre \(O\) and radius \(10\mathrm{cm}\). The chord \(AB\) divides the circle into two regions whose areas are in the ratio 1 : 4 and it is required to find the length of \(AB\). The angle \(AOB\) is \(\theta\) radians.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 324, 151, 343]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 324, 358, 343]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\theta = \frac{2}{5}\pi + \sin \theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 325, 920, 343]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 355, 153, 373]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 355, 920, 405]]<|/det|>
Showing all your working, use an iterative formula, based on the equation in part **(i)**, with an initial value of 2.1, to find \(\theta\) correct to 2 decimal places. Hence find the length of \(AB\) in centimetres correct to 1 decimal place.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 388, 920, 405]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 440, 94, 460]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 433, 524, 472]]<|/det|>
The integral \(I\) is defined by \(I = \int_{0}^{2} 4t^{3} \ln (t^{2} + 1) \mathrm{d}t\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 484, 153, 504]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 484, 678, 520]]<|/det|>
Use the substitution \(x = t^{2} + 1\) to show that \(I = \int_{1}^{5} (2x - 2) \ln x \mathrm{~d}x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 490, 920, 508]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 528, 410, 548]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label> Hence find the exact value of \(I\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 529, 920, 548]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 580, 97, 600]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 574, 507, 603]]<|/det|>
The complex number \(u\) is defined by \(u = \frac{6 - 3\mathrm{i}}{1 + 2\mathrm{i}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 617, 153, 635]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 617, 870, 636]]<|/det|>
Showing all your working, find the modulus of \(u\) and show that the argument of \(u\) is \(- \frac{1}{2}\pi .\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 617, 920, 636]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 650, 153, 670]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 650, 838, 670]]<|/det|>
For complex numbers \(z\) satisfying \(\arg (z - u) = \frac{1}{4}\pi\), find the least possible value of \(|z|\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 682, 151, 700]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 682, 920, 700]]<|/det|>
For complex numbers \(z\) satisfying \(|z - (1 + \mathrm{i})u| = 1\), find the greatest possible value of \(|z|\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 728, 94, 747]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 730, 151, 747]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 730, 556, 747]]<|/det|>
Prove the identity \(\cos 4\theta + 4\cos 2\theta \equiv 8\cos^4\theta - 3\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 730, 920, 749]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 761, 213, 780]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 781, 210, 797]]<|/det|>
Hence

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 787, 180, 806]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 787, 660, 807]]<|/det|>
solve the equation \(\cos 4\theta + 4\cos 2\theta = 1\) for \(- \frac{1}{2}\pi \leqslant \theta \leqslant \frac{1}{2}\pi\),

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 821, 185, 840]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 816, 490, 853]]<|/det|>
find the exact value of \(\int_{0}^{\frac{1}{4}\pi} \cos^{4} \theta \mathrm{~d}\theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 826, 920, 845]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[323, 878, 675, 897]]<|/det|>
**[Question 10 is printed on the next page.]**

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 104, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
The number of birds of a certain species in a forested region is recorded over several years. At time \(t\) years, the number of birds is \(N\), where \(N\) is treated as a continuous variable. The variation in the number of birds is modelled by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[413, 123, 584, 155]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{\mathrm{d}N}{\mathrm{d}t} = \frac{N(1800 - N)}{3600}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 159, 401, 176]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(N = 300\) when \(t = 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[124, 191, 153, 208]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 191, 465, 208]]<|/det|>
Find an expression for \(N\) in terms of \(t\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 191, 920, 208]]<|/det|>
<mark>[9]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 222, 153, 240]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 221, 737, 240]]<|/det|>
According to the model, how many birds will there be after a long time?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 222, 920, 240]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]
